title: Augusta County: J. S. Hubard to Uncle, February 21, 1862
summary: Hubbard writes to his uncle from Staunton about a variety of topics, including the chances of victory for the South, Confederate policies, the low status of nearby women, the polite and refined character of local "Negroes," the folly of empowering the "rabble," illicit trade in horses and whiskey by refugees, and enlistment prospects in his regiment.
keywords: Slavery, Military Authority, National Government, Women, Desertion/Leave, Home Front, Camp Life, Family, American Civil War
